gov.anl.ipns.ViewTools.Components.ViewControls
Class ControlColorScale

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  gov.anl.ipns.ViewTools.UI.ActiveJPanel
                      gov.anl.ipns.ViewTools.Components.ViewControls.ViewControl
                          gov.anl.ipns.ViewTools.Components.ViewControls.ControlColorScale
All Implemented Interfaces:
IPreserveState, IAxisAddible, IOverlayAddible, IPseudoLogAxisAddible, IZoomAddible, IViewControl, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class ControlColorScale
extends ViewControl
implements IPseudoLogAxisAddible

This class is a ViewControl (ActiveJPanel) with a color scale for use by ViewComponents. No messages are sent by this control.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Field Detail

HORIZONTAL

public static final boolean HORIZONTAL
"true" - Use this value to specify a horizontal (x-axis) calibrated colorscale. This variable has no relevance when used with the basic colorscale.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

VERTICAL

public static final boolean VERTICAL
"false" - Use this value to specify a vertical (y-axis) calibrated colorscale. This variable has no relevance when used with the basic colorscale.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

ORIENTATION

public static final java.lang.String ORIENTATION
"Orientation" - This constant String is a key for referencing the state information about the orientation of the colorscale. Static boolean values HORIZONTAL and VERTICAL are used to set the orientation. The value that this key references is a primative boolean.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

COLOR_SCALE

public static final java.lang.String COLOR_SCALE
"Color Scale" - This constant String is a key for referencing the state information about the color scale used for the control. The value that this key references is of type String. These String constants may be found in IndexColorMaker.java.

See Also:
IndexColorMaker, Constant Field Values

TWO_SIDED

public static final java.lang.String TWO_SIDED
"Two Sided" - This constant String is a key for referencing the state information about one or two-sided data. The value that this key references is of type boolean. Values are true if two-sided, false if one-sided.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

LOG_SCALE

public static final java.lang.String LOG_SCALE
"Log Scale" - This constant String is a key for referencing the state information about the intensity or log scale value. This value comes from the intensity slider and is of type float. Values are on the range [0,1].

See Also:
Constant Field Values

MARKER

public static final java.lang.String MARKER
"Marker" - This constant String is a key for referencing the state information about the current pointed-at value position on the colorscale.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

ControlColorScale

public ControlColorScale(java.lang.String colorscale,
                         boolean doublesided)
Constructor creates a basic colorscale without calibration. Possible color schemes are listed in IndexColorMaker.java.

Parameters:
colorscale - Colorscale for this control
doublesided - Is data double-sided?
See Also:
IndexColorMaker

getObjectState

public ObjectState getObjectState(boolean isDefault)
This method will get the current values of the state variables for this object. These variables will be wrapped in an ObjectState.

Specified by:
getObjectState in interface IPreserveState
Specified by:
getObjectState in interface IViewControl
Overrides:
getObjectState in class ViewControl
Parameters:
isDefault - Should selective state be returned, that used to store user preferences common from project to project?
Returns:
if true, the default state containing user preferences, if false, the entire state, suitable for project specific saves.

setTwoSided

public void setTwoSided(boolean is_two_sided)
This method allows the calibrated colorscale to always appear one- or two-sided, depending on the parameter. By setting this, the one/two-sided setting becomes independent of the data.

Parameters:
is_two_sided - If true, data always displayed 2-sided. If false, data always displayed 1-sided.

isTwoSided

public boolean isTwoSided()
This method tells whether the colorscale is two-sided (positive and negative values) or just one sided (positive only).

Returns:
True if two-sided, false if one-sided.

setMarker

public void setMarker(float marker)
This method allows calibrated color scales to trace the current point.

Parameters:
marker - - world coordinate value that needs marking.

setColorScale

public void setColorScale(java.lang.String colorscale,
                          boolean doublesided)
This method sets the color scheme of the ColorScaleImage. Possible color schemes are listed in IndexColorMaker.java.

Parameters:
colorscale - Colorscale for this control
doublesided - Is data double-sided?

getColorScale

public java.lang.String getColorScale()
This method gets the color scheme of the ColorScaleImage. The scheme will be one listed in IndexColorMaker.java.

Returns:
colorscheme

setLogScale

public void setLogScale(double value)
This method sets the logscale of this control. The logscale is only used for calibrated colorscales.

Parameters:
value - Double value on interval [0,100]

getLogScale

public double getLogScale()
This method will get the current log scale value for the slider this control is listening to.

Specified by:
getLogScale in interface IPseudoLogAxisAddible
Returns:
logscale

setAxisVisible

public void setAxisVisible(boolean showAxis)
This method sets the turns the axes on and off.

Parameters:
showAxis - Either on (true) or off (false)

getAxisInformation

public AxisInfo getAxisInformation(int axiscode)
The integer, from AxisInfo integer codes, will determine which axis to get information for. The information is wrapped in an AxisInfo object. This method also tells the axis overlay to display the data in log form.

Specified by:
getAxisInformation in interface IAxisAddible
Parameters:
axiscode -
Returns:
value axisinfo of the component, always in log form. If this is a basic color scale, a dumby value is returned.

getRegionInfo

public java.awt.Rectangle getRegionInfo()
This method will return a rectangle with pixel coordinates corresponding to the desired region.

Specified by:
getRegionInfo in interface IOverlayAddible
Returns:
bounds of the center image.

getLocalCoordBounds

public CoordBounds getLocalCoordBounds()
Stub that returns the "value axis" bounds since the colorscale does not allow zooming. This method is required by IAxisAddible interface.

Specified by:
getLocalCoordBounds in interface IZoomAddible

getGlobalCoordBounds

public CoordBounds getGlobalCoordBounds()
Returns the global world bounds ("value axis bounds") of the colorscale. This method is required by IAxisAddible interface.

Specified by:
getGlobalCoordBounds in interface IZoomAddible

getPrecision

public int getPrecision()
This method will return the precision specified by the user. Precision will be assumed to be 4 if not specified. The axis overlays will call this method to determine the precision.

Specified by:
getPrecision in interface IAxisAddible
Returns:
precision of the component If a basic color scale, -1 is returned.

getFont

public java.awt.Font getFont()
This method will return the font used on by the overlays. The axis overlay will call this to determine what font to use.

Specified by:
getFont in interface IAxisAddible
Specified by:
getFont in interface java.awt.MenuContainer
Overrides:
getFont in class java.awt.Component
Returns:
font of component Note: If a basic (non-calibrated) color scale, the view control font is returned.

getTitle

public java.lang.String getTitle()
This method overloads the ViewControls getTitle() so that no title is passed. Because the axis overlay displays the title, we need to set it to an empty string. The title is already displayed by the titled border.

Specified by:
getTitle in interface IAxisAddible
Specified by:
getTitle in interface IViewControl
Overrides:
getTitle in class ViewControl
Returns:
empty_string

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
For testing purposes only...
